It highlights a need for improved transparency and direct communication with members to address dissatisfaction and prevent negative perceptions.

high_impact_items.subject: Comments from an old Life Member
high_impact_items.summary: A long-term NRA member expressed dissatisfaction with the organization's lack of response to the January 6th events and its continued support for Trump. The member feels the NRA has deviated from its original values and seeks acknowledgment of these concerns.

action_required.action: Acknowledge the concerns raised about NRA's stance on January 6th

high_impact_items.subject: Editorial August 2025
high_impact_items.summary: Mr. Patterson, an NRA member, expresses concern over the organization's lack of transparency and the use of foreign-made products. He requests a shift to Made in America incentives to restore trust. Immediate acknowledgment and internal discussion are needed.

action_required.action: Acknowledge receipt of the email and thank Mr. Patterson for his feedback

high_impact_items.subject: Re: Requested letter/suggestion
high_impact_items.summary: The email suggests modernizing NRA's marketing strategies by leveraging AI, social media, and partnerships with retailers and financial services. It highlights the need for change to maintain relevance and suggests specific actions like membership discounts and NRA-branded credit cards.

action_required.action: Evaluate the feasibility of implementing a membership discount program with retailers

emails.subject: Book
emails.body:
Mr. Bachenberg,
   I read your column in the recent American rifleman and sincerely hope that changes are underway.
  My missive concerns a book I recently finished....... 'Fast and Furious' by Katie Pavlich. This book clearly delineates the level of criminality and blatant lying cover-up of illegal scheming of our federal government to  supply illegal arms to Mexican drug cartels. 
   Ms. Pavlich lays out the plans of Eric Holder and Barack Obama to force gun dealers (legal businessmen) in the U.S. to forge sales paperwork and sell guns to the cartels. This went on for quite a while. A Border Patrol agent was subsequently killed with one of these illegal firearms.
   The lies and deniability of Obama and Holder were grounds for impeachment if they were to become known........they were not.
   We have at present a pro second amendment president but we know the gears are grinding in the anti-gun camp for future assaults on our second amendment. They are planning on how to cheat themselves back into power.
   I feel it would be beneficial to all gun owners if your magazines put a small blip in the publications advocating all second amendment advocates to read this book. I have absolutely no fiduciary interest in this book but consider it a must read for those interested in how low our 'government' can stoop to deny citizens constitutional rights.
                                                                         Sid Gammon

Acknowledge receipt of the suggestion and thank the sender

emails.subject: Hi
emails.body:
Dear Bill, thanks to all you that are cleaning up the mess.
    I knew something was wrong when Ollie North left so soon.  
     I joined long ago to help protect our rights.  
     All the best, James McIntyre 
Sent from my iPhone

emails.subject: Re: Some Things Remain The Same-
emails.body:
Boy would I love it!  As it just so happens, I got another fundraising e mail just this afternoon which I just sent to you-

Can we get rid of John Cornyn of Texas? He is worthless to us a really bad RINO!

JB

On Tuesday, July 29, 2025 at 07:36:53 PM EDT, NRA President <president@nradirector.com> wrote:


Why don’t you get your “friends” together one evening and I’ll call in and will have a little round table of Q&A.

 

Bill

 

From: wd8usa@aol.com [mailto:wd8usa@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, July 29, 2025 4:01 PM
To: NRA President <President@NRADirector.com>
Subject: Re: Some Things Remain The Same-

 

I am telling my friends about the direct communication between the NRA President and myself- They can't believe it!

 

Nice going! JB

 

On Monday, July 28, 2025 at 11:23:53 PM EDT, NRA President <president@nradirector.com> wrote:

 

 

Thank you, this helps a lot in addressing the problems with staff.

 

Have a great week,

 

Bill

 

From: wd8usa@aol.com [mailto:wd8usa@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, July 28, 2025 9:51 PM
To: NRA President <President@NRADirector.com>
Subject: Re: Some Things Remain The Same-

 

The requests are VIA e mail offering gifts for 1,2,3 and life member of course at a DISCOUNT rate- 

 

My membership is good for another year but can't recall  exactly- It might be more as I responded to a request last year and extended my membership at the time and got my free gift which was a small power supply for a computer. 

I never really stopped getting requests for money-

 

Renewal requests were at least twice weekly- some times more- Got one just this week VIA e mail-

 

Got the "banned Gun Giveaway" by mail and e mail too- Of course you had to jump through a hoop to enter without outlaying cash extending my membership! 

 

We have enough problems with Leftists, communists and Democrats to have to deal with all this stuff! 

 

We were very lucky to have survived the 2024 election being out spent again by big margins- Seems only the Left and Democrats are wealthy! 

 

OH and yes, the mailings asking to fund the Navada complex too- 

 

JB 

 

 

On Monday, July 28, 2025 at 08:50:58 PM EDT, NRA President <president@nradirector.com> wrote:

 

 

A couple of questions to help me better understand what the marketing company is doing, not what they are telling us:

Type of membership – 1 yr, 2 yr, 3 yr, 5 yr?

When does your membership expire?

When did you start receiving renewal requests?

How many renewal offers have you received: via email? Text? Phone? And Mail?

 

Thank you.

 

From: wd8usa@aol.com [mailto:wd8usa@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, July 28, 2025 8:16 PM
To: NRA President <President@NRADirector.com>
Subject: Re: Some Things Remain The Same-

 

That is all I needed to hear! Thank you for the response! 

 

Just this afternoon, I got another "renewal" offer! Enough is enough! 

 

I wish the organization well and us too- 

 

We have a high hill to climb what with Democrat obstructionism in DC and hostile politicians just waiting to disarm us all in the name of public safety! 

 

Of course the real objective is absolute control of the masses- JB

 

On Monday, July 28, 2025 at 08:09:25 PM EDT, NRA President <president@nradirector.com> wrote:

 

 

Good evening

 

Thank you for writing and expressing your views.  We need honest communications to fix problems and restore confidence!

 

You are absolutely right about the “constant requests to extend or renew memberships not about to expire-“  This is probably the number one complaint from our members.  We are terminating the contract with marketing contractor after 30+ years in October.  We are completely re-looking at how we communicate with our members and managed membership renewals.  We can’t change 30+ years overnight, but changes are already in the wind and a lot more to come.

 

We are also looking at membership dues.

 

Please bear with us a little longer, change is coming.

 

Bill

 

From: wd8usa@aol.com [mailto:wd8usa@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, July 27, 2025 6:45 PM
To: NRA President <President@NRADirector.com>
Subject: Some Things Remain The Same-

 

In spite of the reorganization of NRA  some things remain the same-  Like constant requests to extend or renew memberships not about to expire- 

 

This has not changed! 

 

I have yet to meet a wealthy NRA member- Most members I know can just make ends meet!  The silent majority long detested by the Democrat Party.

 

I wish the requests to renew or extend memberships would end! JB

emails.subject: Why Did I Join
emails.body:
﻿
I have just read your column in the August 2025 issue of American Hunter, in which you invited members to tell you why they joined the National Rifle Association.

I'm 82 years old and, except for a brief hiatus from the organization (more on that in a minute) have been a member for over forty years. My father introduced me to hunting and fishing at a very early age, and I've done the same with my son and grandson. Looking back forty years or so, Mario Cuomo was the governor of New York State. His ego was as large as his liberalism, and he enjoyed sparing with the media at almost daily press conferences, where he would expound on the superiority of his policies and ideas. The press conference that is still fresh in my mind was about gun control. Reporters were asking about self defense, the shooting sports and other aspects of owning a gun. His outlook was that no one should own a gun. One reporter asked about hunters. His reply? "All hunters want to do is drink beer and cheat on their wives." And he was serious. He tried (lamely) to walk it back the next day, but by then I had joined the NRA.

Back then I realized that many people didn't approve of gun ownership, but it didn't really affect me personally until I realized the governor of my state might be coming after my guns. At that time the NRA required a sponsor to join. A neighbor gladly obliged, and I've been an annual member almost continually since then. I dropped my membership for a period of time since although I firmly believe the NRA is one of the only organizations (the New York Rifle and Pistol Association being another) that will stand and fight for my second amendment rights. Back then I was raising a family and scratching to make ends meet. So I deleted a few memberships and subscriptions for a few years until I was better able to afford them.

I worked in New York State government for thirty years and witnessed bureaucracy that at times was horrible and at other times promising Towards the end of my career I worked for a commissioner who, like you, asked for input. And he got it. His method of addressing problems was not to criticize or attack persons bringing subjects to his attention but rather to ask staff to work together to solve them. His message? Where do we have opportunities for improvement? A slightly different twist on the question of what 's wrong in our organization and who's to blame for it.

It's in this sprit of looking for opportunities for improvement that I offer a few observations for you to consider. First, I realize you need money to survive and carry out your mission. Every (and I mean every) piece of mail I get from you, whether it be from the main organization or a sub group like the NRA-ILA, is asking for donations. It's a common complaint I hear in the fall, and is one reason people are hesitant to join. ("All they want is money, and I don't know what they do with it") I point out that the America Hunter magazine has sections devoted to NRA activities such as court challenges and regional information around the country and I also make sure there are several copies of this magazine lying around my hunting camp.

While I think of it, I have often wished I had some window decals for my vehicles. You used to send them with my annual membership renewal but with your often offered multi-year membership deals that seems to have fallen by the wayside. But wait, you say. You can go to the NRA store and get some. I don't think paying $6.95 for a small window decal and then shelling out $10.95 to ship it is a very good deal. "I'm the NRA and I vote!" was a good one but has since come off with many washings. 

Lastly I would like to encourage the NRA to once again have regional offices at least in those states where the attack on the second amendment is most egregious. Again, I realize this takes money, but here in New York we are faced with Governor Hochul who has taken gun control to an entirely new level with passage of the Safe Act and accompanying legislation. There used to be an office in Albany that was helpful to me years ago. Perhaps you could work something out with the NY Rifle and Pistol Association. Just a thought.

Before I fire off a note to J. Scott Olmstead about missing the point in a letter he received about squirrel hunting last month, I want to wish you luck in your new endeavor. No need to respond to this. Glad to get it off my chest.

Kenneth Goeldner
000018670846

emails.subject: Comments/Questions
emails.body:
As an NRA Life member, I enjoy reading my "Shooting Illustrated" magazine when it arrives. Though, like most people, I'm quite busy with work, and life's daily activities.
 
To the point, mostly through the media, unfortunately, and sometimes in NRA publications, we've read about a number of misuses of power and financial resources made by previous NRA executives. We've also been told about the "vast" changes that have taken place since then, as well as transparency and accountability reforms.
 
We've also have been told about changes in leadership and board members, and have been given a clarion call to "reach out to new members" to support the organization--and, by association, support the Second Amendment itself.
 
As a strong supporter of the Second Amendment, and NRA, what is troubling to read/hear are all of the "issues" that have happened with the NRA organization, and subsequent "redemption"--though, without being told ANY specifics. The "redemption" and ongoing revisions have been discussed in more than a few months of publications. 
 
As an example--in your words--"For far too long, however, past NRA leadership did not do as good of a job as it should have. The status quo managed to drown you out, leaving your concerns and ideas unheard and unheeded. That has all changed." (July 2025 Shooting Illustrated.)
 
Questions remain:
  1. Who *specifically* misused NRA members' contributions?
  2. How many people were involved.
  3. What were the *specific* instances of malfeasance?
  4. Why do members have to hear about NRA improprieties from media outlets--AND, invariably, from outlets who oppose the NRA and the Second Amendment?!
  5. This is the *second* group of NRA leadership administrators who came after Wayne LaPierre resigned. What happened to the first group?
  6. Why did Bob Barr leave?
  7. Why isn't Lieutenant Colonel Oliver North associated with NRA leadership anymore? I've read the Wikipedia account. But, that doesn't explain why he isn't back after changes have been made.
  8. In prior publications NRA members have been admonished for not using our voting rights to elect members. Reason: WE DON'T KNOW THEM! How about providing a forum (online) where we can see/hear these prospective directors/administrators present themselves and their viewpoints?

  9. AGAIN, why do members have to find out ANY *specific* details about major NRA changes through the media or Wikipedia, INSTEAD OF THROUGH THE NRA itself?!
  10. Lastly, this has nothing to do with the points above; however, to save time, I'll state it here: I (like many others) will miss Wiley Clapp and his "Fightin' Iron" articles. I always looked forward to reading them! The space in "Shooting Illustrated" after he left is left wanting. That's about as nice as it can be stated.
Regards,
Mark
--
Mark K. Jowett, Ph.D., BSIT Program Chair
School of Information - Florida's iSchool
College of Communication and Information
Florida State University
142 Collegiate Loop
Tallahassee, Florida 32306-2100
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

emails.subject: Comments from an old Life Member
emails.body:
Good morning Bill,
     I'm only a few months shy of my 75th birthday, and just had my 40th anniversary of being a Life member of the NRA.  Raised in a small coal town in Tioga County, Pennsylvania,  I joined the NRA shortly after graduation in 1968.   Not sure the real reason, but they had a neat magazine (American Rifleman) that all of my shooting buddies read every month.  This was back when you had to have another member sponsor you for joining,...and back when they published the names of the winners of all those gun raffles the following month after the raffle was over.   I never met another member that ever won anything from the NRA.   There were the Cincinnati accords, the birth of the ILA, and later the shakeup there. 

   In retirement now, 20 years total Naval service, 28 years in the nuclear industry, 42 years in the gun business and FFL holder (inspected numerous times by ATF, and never once felt I was dealing with "jack booted thugs" as LaPierre called them), 35 years volunteering in Scouting, NRA Rifle, Shotgun, and RSO qualified, high school coach on shotgun team, current South Carolina Hunter Education instructor, and years of range service at scout camps in the summer.   Obviously a 'gun guy' like your self, and another Pennsylvanian if I remember reading your profile.
   The NRA today is clearly not the NRA I joined in 1968.   

January 6th 2021 changed everything, as former president Trump stood at the oval below the capitol and watched as his supporters stormed and wreaked destruction of the People's House...the US Capitol.     Patiently I waited for a response from the NRA in their publications denouncing Trump's lack of leadership on that fateful day.  It never came.  
  For four years we had to put up with his rhetoric of a stolen election.   The NRA continued to support him solely on his support of the 2nd Amendment.    This was our 'commander in chief'...the captain of our ship, the general of our forces, watching for over three hours as his supporters destroyed the Capitol.   This was the greatest public display of Treason that I have witnessed by a public official in my lifetime.   He should have been relieved immediately, even with only a few days left in the White House.    And yet, not a word from the NRA other than praise....and to have his picture on the front cover of their publications just prior to the election??...that was too much.  The NRA should have dropped his membership on the spot. 
  
  Oliver North did a favor for the NRA by calling for an audit of expenditures.   We didn't get too much detail of the NRA vs. New York state coverage, but the New York Times did provide some detail of the trial, LaPierre's resignation, and his living the life of Riley off the NRA.   It will be interesting to read the details of the 'claw back' expenses that are supposed to be published in the official journals as reported in an issue of American Hunter just a couple of months ago. 

   And now you have Comrade Trump, convicted felon (can't legally own guns if a felon...right?) the NRA's 'law and order' guy, in office again.  Still bashing the Democrats and Joe Biden for everything.   And still supported by the NRA solely on his support for the 2nd Amendment.   But how about all the rest of the Constitution that he doesn't have knowledge of or totally disregards?    Write an executive order for everything, and let the courts challenge it, if you don't get the response you like, bash the judges, and...eventually kick it to the Supreme Court.    Yep, he's the NRA's 'law and order guy'. 
     In my 40 plus years in fixing and selling guns, I know that Democrats and Independents like their guns too, and they have money to spend too.   If you want to grow NRA membership you need to back way down on the politics and get back to the bottom line....guns, training, safety etc.
As a hunter education instructor here in South Carolina, I no longer have any NRA material on the 'give away' table.   As a suggestion for improvement, I would create a new magazine for the ILA and make it optional to receive upon joining.   Put all your political b.s. In one magazine, get it out of AH and AR and give your new director his own platform.  The same old stuff I've heard for years.   I suspect you've lost a lot of advertisers based on the size of my American Hunter magazine alone.  It's about half of what it used to be.           
     The sole reason I haven't cut up my Life Member card and sent half to you and half to Doug is that I have to show a current qualification card at the Scout Camps in order to teach and serve on the gun ranges there.       I know these comments are not those that you want or like to hear from an old Life Member but based on your recent comments in your column, I'll bet there are many more like myself. 
    In closing, I wish you good luck as the new President, as you certainly have your work cut out for you in restoring trust and respect to the organization. 
Good hunting up there in Pa.!

Stanley M. 'Mike' Janeski
Rock Hill, South Carolina

emails.subject: Change
emails.body:
Mr. Bachenberg,
The updated organization in comparison to the way things were is impressive. The American Hunter magazine is great in style and usefull information. I'm a farmer and was very apprecative of the update on the screw worm. The article about the the brown bear by boat was super.
Change comes with a great price when the ship has been run aground, but take heart, the NEW NRA is emerging, and it looks great!
Keep doing the next right thing.....full steam ahead!
Regards,
Dennis Flanery 
Holden,Mo

emails.subject: Re: Mr. Bachenberg.
emails.body:
Glad to hear your response and waiting to see the results.  God Bless America and anxious to see NRA in the MAGA forum!
Sent from my iPhone

> On Jul 28, 2025, at 6:46 PM, NRA President <President@nradirector.com> wrote:
> 
> ﻿Good evening Mike,
> 
> NRA has a great new leadership team that is working almost 24x7.  We have made great progress in the areas of Transparency and Accountability.  My next column will talk about cleaning out those that lack integrity from the board committees.
> 
> I was probably making $2.50 an hour when I purchased my life membership and it was a long time saving.  I fully understand how hard many of our members work to join the NRA.  As a past farmer, every dollar is precious and I will endeavor to spend it wisely.
> 
> Your new leadership team are strong businessman and acting like DOGE.  We don't just sign-off on large expenitures, they are examined and challenged for the best our member's best interest.
> 
> President Trump is supportive of the new NRA 2.0. Let's work together and Make NRA Great Again.  
> 
> Bill
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Perry [mailto:mike.perry.201010@gmail.com]
> Sent: Sunday, July 27, 2025 9:36 PM
> To: NRA President <President@NRADirector.com>
> Subject: Mr. Bachenberg.
> 
> Hope you are the “Trump” person to lead the NRA thru this critical phase of lost confidence and trust.  I am retired and have always renewed yearly.
>   If you and your board can’t make a statement with Trump behind you then bring in DOGE and Elon to set a new official goal for the direction of our rights under the constitution.
> Talk is cheap when you’re spending someone’s money.
> Sent from my iPhone

emails.subject: Editorial August 2025
emails.body:
Dear Mr. Bachenberg,

Thank you for your editorial in the NRA August 2025 issue. I especially like your verbiage of principled transparency and honesty. Many members have lost trust in the NRA because of the lack of the above mentioned values. Rumors that exist are like smoke from a fire. One of the most obscene practices of the NRA is giving stuff away made in China. I have written two letters to Mr. Doug Hamlin concerning this. We, my friend, are the NRA of AMERICA. Please address this and provide Made in America only incentives.

Respectfully,

Wayne Patterson
NRA Member # 000144155381

specific_topics: use of products made in China

Discuss internally the feasibility of sourcing Made in America incentives
Prepare a public statement addressing concerns about transparency and product sourcing

Negative perception due to foreign-made products

Promote Made in America products

emails.subject: Re: Requested letter/suggestion
emails.body:
NRA MARKETING STRATAGIES

The NRA should be like the phoenix and rise, again, from the ashes. The old ways of marketing, by the NRA, has become old, stale and not very effective. This is 2025 and the NRA needs to embrace what this new age of computers, AI, social media and new age marketing has to offer. Below are some ideas worth considering to get the NRA back to its glory days.

1.   Have every gun store, brick & mortar and online, a voice of the NRA. In my previous email, I mentioned how to set up a website that any retail outlet can access, to enter a member’s NRA number to get an immediate discount of their purchase and to reimburse the dealer. Since every membership these days (think Amazon, Costco, Sam’s Club, Walmart+, etc.) pay an annual fee to be a member, charge every retailer and FFL dealer an annual fee of (e.g.) $120 to offer the NRA discount and to receive banners and posters about being proud members of the NRA. Use these annual fees to defray the cost of the website and to cover the X% discount for being an NRA member.

2.   Offer the participating retailers and FFLs an inside track to NRA supported credit card processing services, business bank accounts by supporting banks, business insurance, liability insurance, internet services, etc. Any service needed for a business to operate can be offered to an NRA supporting retail business. This is similar to the NRA insurance offered to gun ranges and clubs where its members are all NRA members.

3.   Offer, at the retail outlets, an NRA Visa/Master Card underwritten by an internet bank that specializes in the new credit/light credit market. These finance companies offer credit cars with a limited $500 to $1000 credit limit for new credit buyers. Use the gun purchase as collateral (unenforceable) and give these retail shops a way to sell more guns to more people or to upsell a buyer from a “cheap” purchase to a “better”one with a new credit card issued THRU a lender recognized by the NRA. Of course, a membership would also be needed to qualify but it can be added to the new credit card.

4.   Make the NRA membership card a valuable commodity to the membership. For example, look at how the AARP offers its members hundreds of saving options. Have the NRA membership card be as valuable as an AARP card to the membership. Offer sponsored discounts to specific gas stations, restaurants, fast food joints, etc. For members on the go, visit a Cracker Barrel restaurant, present your NRA card and get a 10% discount on the food bill. The restaurant gets the increased business from NRA members because the NRA Rifleman magazine publishes a page(s) of sponsors that support the NRA and who we should patronize. NRA members are very supportive of those who believe in us. We are a loyal group. The NRA card can be digital as well as physical and can have a QR code to be used easily. This is 2025.

 

By making being an NRA member a privilege instead of just another bill, the NRA can become as big and powerful as any organization that provides value in membership. All it takes is some clever, 2025 type marketing, to get the ball rolling. With social media taking over, the right marketing can snowball immediate results.

 

However, the core of the NRA mission must be front and center. That can never change but offering ways for the membership to save money is what it takes to get them to want to join us.

 

Larry Hall

Ph)860-921-3791


On Mon, Jul 28, 2025 at 8:47 PM NRA President <President@nradirector.com> wrote:

Good evening Larry, thank you for writing and expressing your views.  We need honest communications to fix problems and restore confidence!

 

Not sure where to start so I’m embedding my responses.

 

From: Larry Hall [mailto:larryh1108@gmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, July 27, 2025 12:18 PM
To: NRA President <President@NRADirector.com>
Subject: Requested letter/suggestion

 

Hi,

I am an NRA Benefactor Lifetime Member and have been for many years. I read and appreciate your letter to us in the August 2025 edition. It was a welcome sight and one that was long past due.  I hope you got to read my first column in the July issue.

I had become discouraged about the state of the NRA over the past several years. I was never ashamed of being an NRA member but I was not proud, either. I know so many of us were disillusioned about our present and future that I felt that the end of the NRA was close. I was so happy to see the shakeup that recently happened and the new direction that seems to have been committed to. If our forward movement continues, as you outlined, we can then become an organization that we are proud of, and support, rather than hide from and keep to ourselves.

Here is a little background:

I understand your frustration, because I too was frustrated.  I was only one of seventy-six board members with very little power. You saw what happened with much more powerful board members like Col. North.  In the early days leadership kept the board in the dark like a mushroom and fed us very little information, or lies.  Old leadership assured us everything was fine and we had little hard materials at the time to question them.  In addition, our attorney said we could not speak out during the court case, that was bullshit advice too.  Once some of us got access to factual information, mainly from the court proceedings, we could rise up and educate other board members while still being told everything is fine.  They fed us all bullshit.  Since I was out spoken and elected 1st VP I was hauled in by the NY AG for depositions and then last fall in front of the judge for over two hours.

 

Last year I was prepared to resign if not elected 1st Vice President, you can only beat your head against the wall for so long.  There needed to be significant change in leadership, but the old leadership controlled everything.  Initially there was two of us, then 6, then 11, then 16 board member Patriots that worked tirelessly to get a new leadership team elected so we could enact the much needed change.  It was never my intent to run for leadership, but near the elections it became apparent we needed businessman leadership and ran.  Our team of candidates ran against all the odds against leadership change.  After winning, we were told for the first time in 153 years new leadership was elected from the floor and not from the Nominating Committee’s recommendations which the old leadership team controlled.  Unfortunately last year our president candidate lost by a few votes, but myself, the 2nd Vice President and the EVP were elected by very slim margins.  That president and the Cabal were diametrically opposed to the Vice Presidents so we steam rolled over the president and the remnants of the old leaders to start exposing what was going on and making changes for the good of the members.  The EVP was extremely supportive.

 

Since you said that you have our ears, I wish to ramble on about many things that I would like to see changed. I am not speaking for only myself, but for many I have spoken with over the years. What I am writing is a voice of many, not just one. I hope you receive it with the intent given and not as a slam against a great organization. I am writing this from the front lone, not the ivory towers or the elite. I am speaking for the blue-collar members and non-members who are hesitant to join. Hopefully we get your ears.

#1 is that we need to get back to, and to be known for, what made us great to start with. The basics: educating our youths about safe gun handling as well as learning how to shoot responsibly. Training camps, shooting contests, proper storage and keeping our guns clean and functional. The basics that every person who holds a gun should know by heart.

How? By offering free seminars and camps. Free because so many of us cannot afford the $100 entry and another $100 for ammo and another for gas to get there and another $100 for accommodations and meals, etc. I know I would gladly contribute to specified outings because I knew where my money was going. Donating before meant we had no idea how much went to support events and how much went to chartered flights private jets, thousand dollars steaks, etc. I stopped giving when I didn’t know where the money went. If 10% of what I donated went to a cause, that didn’t work for me. If 90% goes to training our kids, count me in.

I’m hosting the first ever in a 154 years “Committee Chairman Weekend Retreat” to re-imagine NRA 2.0 in August.  This will be a brainstorming and strategic planning weekend.  The current agenda will be addressing many of your concerns.  All attendees are paying their own way.

#2. STOP WITH THE SPAM, AGGRESSIVE AND ANNOYING TELEMARKETING! I mean it. Every number I got from the NRA on my incoming calls has been blocked. I don’t want to hear it. I won’t answer it and I blocked every number. Telemarketing is so low on the slimy list that it has ruined our reputation to everybody. Just stop it!

You are absolutely right!!!!!!  This is probably the number one complaint from our members.  We are terminating the contract with marketing contractor after 30+ years in October – new leadership.  We are completely re-looking at how we communicate with our members and managed membership renewals.  We can’t change 30+ years overnight, but changes are already in the wind and a lot more to come.

 

#3 STOP WITH THE CHICKEN LITTLE, END OF THE WORLD direct mailings. Just stop wasting money. If you know what Chicken Little means then you know that crying the end of the world long enough, no one listens any more. These horrible letters got old decades ago yet they still come! Yes, every administration wants to take our guns. We know that! But to send letter after letter telling us this is the worst it’s ever been and you need our money TODAY to fight it has become the joke of direct mail. The NRA has become a laughing stock! I never open ANY mail from the NRA because it’s full of nonsense and drama. Every mailing costs, what $5 million dollars? Any NRA mail I get is shredded immediately, never opened. I am tired of the begging and nonsense. Enough is enough and the NRA crossed that line a long time ago.

Again I agree 1,000%, the last mailing was insane … this is another reason why the marketing company is being terminated and the Board is taking an active role is the future of marketing.

#4 I DON’T WANT TO REGISTER FOR A FREE TRUCK OR ENDANGERED RIFLE OR ANOTHER KNIFE OR DUFFEL BAG IF I DONATE! Enough! Goes straight to the garbage! What am I donating to? The general fund? How much of my donation actually goes to something worthwhile? 25%? 10%? 50%? How much? Is the NRA a bureaucracy or an organization that truly help it’s members or executives?

Great questions, everything we do from now will be based on Return on Investment “ROI” as to the cost, the return and who it helps.

I know this has become redundant but the message is the same. The NRA used to be about begging for money every email, direct mail, phone call and message. Yes, the NRA does need money for it’s mission. No doubt. Your August 2025 letter to stated that you’re becoming transparent. If that is true and you earn back our trust, then the money will begin to roll in. We have money to donate. We want to donate but we want to know what we are donating to. Dinners or causes? Private jets or gun rights? What? Tell us. We’ll listen.

Every employee and board member must complete a Conflict of Interest form, we have a whistleblower hotline and compliance looks into everything.  Last week we just talked about giving donors the option of where their donations can be designated.  We are not there yet, but being considered.

Yes, I’ve mentioned a few things that annoy me to no end. You’ve mentioned that you know we are fed up and want change and that you are heading in that direction. If true, we will rise again. If your present marketing continues with it’s horrible and outdated methods, then we will cease to exist. You need to find a MUCH BETTER way to market the NRA to the general public.

If the NRA marketed Sushi, they would call it cold, dead, raw fish.  This is a major focus area for new leadership.

I’ve complained but I have some answers as well. No use complaining without some solutions. That’s not right.

First, ask yourself this: If an estimated 150 million households have a gun in their home, how many homes know the 4 rules of safety? Safe storage? Actually how to safely aim and shoot? How may are NRA members?

We have around 4 million members and 30 million gun owners identify as NRA members.  Eddie Eagle has been presented to over 32 million children.  Tons more to go.

How can such an important organization, a true American icon, have such a small percentage of American households as members? How is that possible? The NRA is THE grassroots organization for America yet such a small percentage have joined? I assume it’s because of the terrible reputation that was earned during these last 20 years when we needed the support the most yet the NRA became the tackiest it’s even been. The NRA was also the strongest it needed to be to go against Obama and the anti-gun lobby. The NRA was so strong yet lost so much credibility during these times. How can this be?

Simple, old leadership lost focus and got fat..

We need to get an immediate increase in our membership so the newest members can see how good we are, not how tacky we are. How do we do this without the slimy telemarketing and phony direct mail? Well, I have a suggestion:

A)     Enlist every gun shop to ask a question during any gun or ammo purchase. Ask if the buyer is an NRA current member for an X% discount. If the answer is “yes”, have them get the member number, give them the X% discount and have an online NRA website to get reimbursed from the NRA. Have this website generate an email to the member thanking them for the purchase and offering (something) for their renewal.

B)     If the buyer says “no”, complete the transaction as usual but tell them that the NRA will send them a free 1-year membership, at no cost with no credit card number, etc. The store then enters the buyers name, address, email, phone, etc into the NRA website. Each time the gun shop enters a “new” member, he gets XX points that can be used towards XX gifts, plaques, t-shirts or whatever, e.g. each “new” NRA logged in gets the shop 100 points. At 1000 points they can get a t-shirt or 5000 points gets an NRA knife, etc. The stuff the NRA gives now while begging to donations. With this free membership, the NRA can send a welcome letter that is classy and explains our mission. No slime. No begging for money, just a warm welcome. Also, send them a free Rifleman subscription. This is one of the best magazines of any kind out there. It is a real gem. Get it in their hands. Send them the link for the online magazine as well. Let them see what we do without pushy marketing. Don’t spam emails. Don’t ever call. Just let them absorb who we are and what we do.  After 10 months, ask them what they think. If we convert 10%, we did good. Very good.

 

We need 50 million members, not 5 million. If we are classy and informative and not pushy and cheesy, we should revive our mission. Send me an email or direct mail saying we need every member to donate $10 so we can offer this to our gun dealers, count me in. Ask for $25 for a free knife and count me out. Tell me where my money is going and I may donate. Offer me a chance to win a truck and it goes into the shredder.

I greatly appreciate the above, this is a great idea that I have already sent to our Membership Committee.  Please keep the ideas coming.

 

 

I hope this made sense. You seemed humble and honest in your letter to us. Hopefully you back it up with actions because words are just that…. Words.

 

I can be reached by reply to this email. I think all my NRA phone lines are blocked. If you want to reply, hit reply. I am right here. Otherwise, do what you say you will. I’ve had enough of hollow promises.

No hollow promises, we are running at WARP speed and asking Scottie for more powerJ It’s a big battleship to turn.

When I testified in front of the judge, I said “… this is a new NRA, NRA 2.0.”  In the judge’s decision last Fall he stated he trusted the two vice presidents (Mark Vaughan and I) that they would not allow back-sliding, and we will not.  I asked for the following video to be produced by a friend for the new NRA 2.0 pledge https://youtu.be/sdGgcHw4I2c

 

As I said in my first President’s column “Actions speak louder than words.”  We are working expeditiously on positive change for the future.  We now have a strong board working for the NRA members and protecting the Second Amendment.  If you ever hear of anything that concerns you please contact me and I will do my best to address and will reported back to you.

 

Thank you Larry

 

 

Larry Hall

NRA Benefactor Member

needs_response_today.subject: Re: Some Things Remain The Same-
